lines.content: Welcome to **Shrek**, your friendly assistant designed to help you manage tasks efficiently! Whether you're looking to track deadlines or find specific tasks, **Shrek** is here to assist you.
- **Task Management**: Add, mark, unmark, and delete tasks.
- **Find Tasks**: Quickly search for tasks using keywords.
- **Event Management**: Schedule events with start and end times.
- **Flexible Input**: If you type anything that is not a recognized command, **Shrek** will simply keep that input as a task.
To start using **Shrek**, follow these steps:
2. Interact with the chatbot by typing commands in the input field.
- **deadline [description] /by [date]**: Add a task with a deadline.
- **event [description] /from [start time] /to [end time]**: Add an event task.
- **mark [task number]**: Mark a task as done.
- **delete [task number]**: Remove a task from the list.
- **find [keyword]**: Search for tasks containing the specified keyword.
- To add a todo task: `todo Finish the report`
- To set a deadline: `deadline Submit assignment /by 2024-09-30`
- To input anything else: `Any other input will be kept as a note in the list.`
- **Solution**: Ensure the application is running. Restart if necessary.
- **Issue**: I entered a command, but it did not work.
- **Solution**: Check the command format. Ensure you follow the command syntax.
Thank you for using **Shrek**! We hope you enjoy managing your tasks with our chatbot. If you have any feedback or questions, please reach out!
* The Deadline class represents a task with a deadline.
* It extends the Task class to provide specific functionality for deadline tasks.
* Constructs a Deadline object with the specified description and deadline.
* @param description the description of the deadline task
* @param by the deadline date/time for the task
* Returns a string representation of the deadline task, including its status, description, and deadline.
* @return a formatted string representing the deadline task
* Returns a string representation of the deadline task in a format suitable for saving to a file.
* @return a formatted string representing the deadline task for saving
* The Event class represents a task that occurs at a specific time interval.
* It extends the Task class to provide specific functionality for event tasks.
* Constructs an Event object with the specified description, start time, and end time.
* @param description the description of the event task
* @param from the starting time of the event
* @param to the ending time of the event
public Event(String description, String from, String to) { //constructor for event.
* Returns a string representation of the event task, including its status, description, and time interval.
* @return a formatted string representing the event task
return "[E][" + getStatusIcon() + "] " + getDescription() + " (from: " + from + " to: " + to + ")";
* Returns a string representation of the event task in a format suitable for saving to a file.
* @return a formatted string representing the event task for saving
* The main entry point of the task management software.
* This class sets up the necessary components and starts the application,
* managing the initialization of the UI, task list, storage, and parser.
* The main method that starts the Duke application.
* Initializes the user interface, task list, storage, and parser to handle user commands.
* @param args Command-line arguments passed to the program (not used).
Ui ui = new Ui(); //Create instance of UI to handle user interaction
Storage storage = new Storage("data/duke.txt"); // Create a Storage instance, specifying the file path
//load tasks from file at the start
taskList = new TaskList(); //initialise empty list if file is not found
Parser parser = new Parser(ui, storage, taskList); // Create a parser instance, passing in the UI, Storage and task list
* The Parser class handles the interpretation of user commands and the execution of corresponding actions.
* It interacts with the UI, storage, and task list to manage tasks effectively.
* Constructs a Parser object with the specified UI, storage, and task list.
* @param ui the user interface for interacting with the user
* @param storage the storage object for saving and loading tasks
* @param tasks the task list containing the current tasks

* The Storage class handles the loading and saving of tasks to and from a txt file at a predefined path.
* It provides methods to read tasks from a file and save tasks to a file.

* @param filePath the path to the file where tasks will be stored

* @return an ArrayList of Task objects loaded from the file
* @throws FileNotFoundException if the file does not exist

* The Task class represents a task with a description and a status indicating whether it is done.
* Constructs a Task object with the specified description.
* @param description the description of the task
* Returns the status icon of the task.
* @return "X" if the task is done, otherwise returns a space
return (isDone ? "X" : " "); // mark done task with X, empty space otherwise.
* Returns the description of the task.
* Checks if the task is done.
* @return true if the task is done, otherwise false
* Marks the task as not done.
* Returns a string representation of the task, including its status and description.
* Returns a string representation of the task in a format suitable for saving to a file.
* @return a formatted string representing the task for saving
* The TaskList class manages a list of tasks.
* It provides methods to add, delete, retrieve, and find tasks within the list.
// Constructor for initializing an empty task list
* Adds a task to the list.
* @param task the Task object to be added to the list
* Removes a task from the list by its index.
* @param index the index of the task to remove
* @throws IndexOutOfBoundsException if the index is out of range
throw new IndexOutOfBoundsException("Task index out of range");
* Retrieves a task by its index.
* @param index the index of the task to retrieve
* @return the Task object at the specified index
* @throws IndexOutOfBoundsException if the index is out of range
throw new IndexOutOfBoundsException("Task index out of range");
* Returns the number of tasks in the list.
* @return the size of the task list
* Returns a copy of all tasks in the list.
* @return an ArrayList containing all Task objects in the list
return new ArrayList<>(tasks);  // Returns a copy of the tasks list
* Finds and returns tasks that contain the specified keyword in their description.
* @param keyword the keyword to search for in task descriptions
* @return an ArrayList of Task objects that match the keyword
* The Todo class represents a task that is a to-do item.
* It extends the Task class to provide specific functionality for to-do tasks.
* Constructs a Todo object with the specified description.
* @param description the description of the to-do task
* Returns a string representation of the to-do task, including its status and description.
* @return a formatted string representing the to-do task
* Returns a string representation of the to-do task in a format suitable for saving to a file.
* @return a formatted string representing the to-do task for saving
* The Ui class handles the user interface for the task management application.
* It provides methods for displaying messages and interacting with the user.
* Constructs a Ui object and initializes the scanner for user input.
* Displays a horizontal line to the console.
* Displays a welcome message to the user.
System.out.println("What are you doing in my swamp!??");
* Reads a command inputted by the user.
* @return the user input as a String
* Displays an error message when no previous task data is found.
System.out.println("No previous task data found. Starting with an empty list.");
* Displays a message indicating that a task has been added.
* @param task     the task that was added
* @param taskCount the total number of tasks after addition
public void showTaskAdded(Task task, int taskCount) {
System.out.println("I've added this task to your pile of nonsense:");
System.out.println("Now you have " + taskCount + " tasks in my swamp.");
* Displays the current list of tasks.
* @param tasks the TaskList containing the current tasks
System.out.println("Here is your list of nonsense, now get out of my swamp:");
System.out.println("     " + (i + 1) + "." + tasks.getTask(i));  // Uses Task's toString() method
* Displays a message indicating that a task has been marked as done.
* @param task the task that was marked as done
System.out.println("Its done. Now, get lost before I toss you out of my swamp!");
* Displays a message indicating that a task has been unmarked.
* @param task the task that was unmarked
System.out.println("Its unmarked. Gonna change it again? Make up your mind, or get out of my swamp!");
* Displays a message indicating that a task has been deleted.
* @param task the task that was deleted
System.out.println("Fine Ill remove this task donkey:");
System.out.println("No such tasks in my swamp!");
System.out.println("Here's what i dug out from my swamp.");
* Displays a format error message when the user input is incorrect.
System.out.println("Wrong format, enter a valid task.");
* Displays an index error message when the user tries to access a non-existent task.
System.out.println("That task is not even in my swamp donkey! Try another task.");
* Displays an input error message when the user input is invalid.
System.out.println("What are you typing donkey? Specify the time/task right or get out of my swamp.");
* Displays a goodbye message when the user exits the application.
System.out.println("Finally, youre leaving. Now I can have some peace in my swamp.");
* Displays an error message when saving a file fails.
